{{redirect|IBEX|other uses|Ibex (disambiguation)}} {{Update|date=July 2013}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox spaceflight |auto=all | name = Interstellar Boundary Explorer | names_list = Explorer 91
SMEX-10 | image = IBEX spacecraft.jpg | image_caption = | image_size = | mission_type = Astronomy | operator = [[NASA]] | COSPAR_ID = 2008-051A | SATCAT = 33401 | website = http://ibex.swri.edu/ | mission_duration = Planned: 2 years
Elapsed: {{time interval|19 October 2008 17:47:23|show=ymd|sep=,}} | spacecraft_bus = MicroStar-1 | manufacturer = [[Orbital Sciences Corporation|Orbital Sciences]] | launch_mass = {{convert|107|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web |url=https://directory.eoportal.org/web/eoportal/satellite-missions/i/ibex |title=IBEX (Interstellar Boundary Explorer) |work=eoPortal |publisher=[[European Space Agency]] |accessdate=August 13, 2015}} | dry_mass = {{convert|80|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} | payload_mass = {{convert|26|kg|lb|0|abbr=on}} | dimensions = {{convert|95|xx|58|cm|in|abbr=on}} | power = 66 W (116 W max) | launch_date = {{start-date|October 19, 2008, 17:47:23|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Pegasus (rocket)|Pegasus XL]] | launch_site = {{nowrap|''[[Stargazer (aircraft)|Stargazer]]'', [[Bucholz Army Airfield|Bucholz Airfield]]}} | launch_contractor = [[Orbital Sciences Corporation|Orbital Sciences]] | entered_service = January 2009 | disposal_type = | deactivated = | last_contact = | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[High Earth orbit|High Earth]] | orbit_semimajor = {{cvt|{{#expr:(3.986004418e5 * (86400/(2*pi*0.095053))^2)^(1/3)}}|km|mi|0|adj=ri0}} | orbit_eccentricity = 0.6586277 | orbit_periapsis = {{cvt|62855|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{cvt|330008|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 26.0179° | orbit_period = {{#expr:1440/0.10313265 round 2}} min | orbit_RAAN = 93.9503° | orbit_arg_periapsis = 22.5731° | orbit_mean_anomaly = 356.6008° | orbit_mean_motion = 0.095053 rev/day | orbit_epoch = 11 June 2017 20:05:05 UTC{{cite web |url=http://heavens-above.com/orbit.aspx?satid=33401 |title=IBEX - Orbit |publisher=Heavens Above |date=June 11, 2017 |accessdate=April 2, 2018}} | orbit_rev_number = 393 | apsis = gee | instruments = IBEX-Lo, IBEX-Hi | programme = [[Explorers program]] | previous_mission = 90: [[Aeronomy of Ice in the Mesosphere|AIM]] | next_mission = 92: [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer|WISE]] }} '''Interstellar Boundary Explorer''' ('''IBEX''') is a [[NASA]] satellite that is making a map of the boundary between the [[Solar System]] and [[interstellar space]]. The mission is part of NASA's [[Small Explorer program]] and was launched with a [[Pegasus (rocket)|Pegasus-XL]] rocket on October 19, 2008.{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/pegasus/ibex/status.html |title=Mission Status Center: Pegasus/IBEX |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Justin |last=Ray |date=October 19, 2008 |accessdate=November 27, 2009}} The design and operation of the mission is being led by the [[Southwest Research Institute]], with the [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] and the [[Lockheed Martin]] Advanced Technology Center serving as co-investigator institutions responsible for the IBEX-Hi and IBEX-Lo sensors respectively. The [[Orbital Sciences Corporation]] manufactured the [[spacecraft bus]] and was the location for spacecraft environmental testing. The nominal mission baseline duration was two years to observe the entire Solar System boundary. This was completed by 2011 and its mission was extended to 2013 to continue observations.{{cite web |url=http://ibex.swri.edu/archive/index.shtml |title=Archived Updates |publisher=Southwest Research Institute}} IBEX is in a Sun-oriented spin-stabilized orbit around the Earth.{{cite web |url=http://www.orbitalatk.com/space-systems/science-national-security-satellites/science-environment-satellites/docs/IBEX.pdf |title=Fact Sheet: IBEX |publisher=Orbital ATK |accessdate=April 27, 2015 |id=FS001_06_3695 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316113810/http://www.orbitalatk.com/space-systems/science-national-security-satellites/science-environment-satellites/docs/IBEX.pdf |archivedate=March 16, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} In June 2011, IBEX was shifted to a new more efficient orbit. It does not come as close to the [[Moon]] in the new orbit, and expends less fuel to maintain its position. == Payload == [[File:IBEX Lo sensor.jpg|thumb|170px|left|IBEX Lo sensor]] The heliospheric boundary of the [[Solar System]] is being imaged by measuring the location and magnitude of charge-exchange collisions occurring in all directions. This will ultimately yield a map of the [[termination shock]] of the [[solar wind]]. The satellite's payload consists of two [[energetic neutral atom]] (ENA) imagers, IBEX-Hi and IBEX-Lo. Each of these sensors consists of a [[collimator]] that limits their fields-of-view, a conversion surface to convert neutral [[hydrogen]] and [[oxygen]] into [[ions]], an [[electrostatic analyzer]] (ESA) to suppress [[ultraviolet]] light and to select ions of a specific energy range, and a detector to count particles and identify the type of each ion. The IBEX-Hi instrument is recording particle counts in a higher energy band than the IBEX-Lo does. The scientific payload also includes a Combined Electronics Unit (CEU) that controls the voltages on the collimator and the ESA, and it reads and records data from the particle detectors of each sensor. == Mission parameters == The IBEX satellite, initially launched into a highly-elliptical transfer orbit with a low perigee, used a [[solid fuel rocket motor]] as its final boost stage at apogee, in order to raise its perigee greatly and to achieve its desired high-altitude elliptical orbit. IBEX is in a highly-eccentric elliptical terrestrial orbit, which ranges from a [[perigee]] of about {{convert|86000|km|mi|abbr=on}} to an [[apogee]] of about {{convert|260000|km|mi|abbr=on}}. Its original orbit was about {{convert|7000|by|320000|km|mi|abbr=on}}—that is, about 80% of the distance to the [[Moon]]—which has changed primarily due to an intentional adjustment to prolong the spacecraft's useful life (see [[#Orbit adjusted|Orbit adjusted]] below). This very high orbit allows the IBEX satellite to move out of the Earth's [[magnetosphere]] when making scientific observations. This extreme altitude is critical due to the amount of charged-particle interference that would occur while taking measurements within the magnetosphere. When within the magnetosphere of the Earth ({{convert|70000|km|disp=or|abbr=on}}), the satellite also performs other functions, including [[telemetry]] downlinks.{{Citation needed|date=August 2015}} == Launch == The IBEX satellite was mated to its [[Pegasus (rocket)|Pegasus]] XL rocket at [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]], [[California]], and the combined vehicle was then suspended below the [[Lockheed L-1011]] ''[[Stargazer (aircraft)|Stargazer]]'' mother airplane and flown to [[Kwajalein Atoll]] in the Central [[Pacific Ocean]], a several-hours-long flight.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/kennedy/launchingrockets/status/2008/elvstatus-20081003.html |title=Expendable Launch Vehicle Status Report |publisher=[[NASA]] |first=George |last=Diller |date=October 3, 2008 |id=ELV-100308}} ''Stargazer'' arrived at Kwajalein on Sunday, October 12, 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/ibex/index.html |title=Interstellar Boundary Explorer Mission |publisher=NASA |date=October 14, 2008}} The IBEX satellite was carried into space on October 19, 2008, by the Pegasus XL rocket. The rocket was released from ''Stargazer'', which took off from Kwajalein, at 17:47:23 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]. By launching from this site close to the [[Equator]], the Pegasus rocket lifted as much as {{convert|35|lb|kg|order=flip|abbr=on}} more mass to orbit than it would have with a launch from the [[Kennedy Space Center]] in [[Florida]].{{cite web |url=http://ibex.swri.edu/archive/2006.11.shtml |title=Janet Ball, Lockheed Martin Space Systems |publisher=Southwest Research Institute |first=Dave |last=McComas |date=November 2006 |accessdate=November 19, 2009}} === Orbit adjusted === In June 2011 IBEX shifted to a new orbit that raised its perigee to more than {{convert|30000|km}}. The new orbit avoids taking the spacecraft too close to the Moon, whose gravity can negatively affect IBEX's orbit. Now the spacecraft uses less fuel to maintain a stable orbit, increasing its useful lifespan to more than 40 years.{{cite web |url=http://ibex.swri.edu/archive/2011.11.14.shtml |title=IBEX Orbit-Raising Maneuver |publisher=Southwest Research Institute |first=Dave |last=McComas |date=November 14, 2011 |accessdate=March 1, 2012}} == Data collection == [[File:IBEX map of the heliosphere, 0.9-1.5 keV.jpg|thumb|High-energy map of the heliosphere]] [[File:IBEXmagneticfieldinfluence.jpg|thumb|left|The ribbon of ENA emissions seen in the IBEX map]] IBEX is collecting [[energetic neutral atom]] (ENA) emissions that are traveling through the Solar System to Earth that cannot be measured by conventional telescopes. These ENAs are created on the boundary of our Solar System by the interactions between [[solar wind]] particles and interstellar medium particles.{{cite news |url=http://ibex.swri.edu/archive/2009.10.15.shtml |title=First Science Results from IBEX! |publisher=Southwest Research Institute |first=Dave |last=McComas |date=October 15, 2009 |accessdate=September 5, 2010}} On the average IBEX-Hi detects about 500 particles per day, and IBEX-Lo, less than 100.{{cite news |url=http://ibex.swri.edu/archive/2012.10.15.shtml |title=3 Years of IBEX Observations |publisher=Southwest Research Institute |first=Dave |last=McComas |date=October 15, 2012}} By 2012, over 100 scientific papers related to IBEX were published, described by the [[Principal Investigator|PI]] as "an incredible scientific harvest". == Astronomical results == [[File:IBEX Heliotail Observations.ogg|thumb|300px|Animation illustrating IBEX's collection of data on neutral atoms at the boundary of the Solar System.]] Initial data revealed a previously unpredicted "very narrow ribbon that is two to three times brighter than anything else in the sky".{{cite news |url=http://www.astronomynow.com/news/n0910/15IBEX/ |title=IBEX maps edge of Solar System |work=Astronomy Now |first=Emily |last=Baldwin |date=October 15, 2009 |accessdate=August 14, 2016}} Initial interpretations suggest that "the interstellar environment has far more influence on structuring the heliosphere than anyone previously believed". It is unknown what is creating the [[energetic neutral atom|ENA (energetic neutral atoms)]] ribbon.{{cite news |url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/326/5951/350.1 |title=Tying Up the Solar System With a Ribbon of Charged Particles |work=[[Science (magazine)|Science]] |first=Richard A. |last=Kerr |volume=326 |issue=5951 |pages=350–351 |date=October 16, 2009 |doi=10.1126/science.326_350a}} The Sun is currently traveling through the [[Local Interstellar Cloud]], and the heliosphere's size and shape are key factors in determining its shielding power from [[cosmic ray]]s. Should IBEX detect changes in the shape of the ribbon, that could show how the heliosphere is interacting with the [[Local Interstellar Cloud|Local Fluff]].{{cite news |url=http://archive.cosmosmagazine.com/news/mysterious-band-particles-holds-clues-solar-systems-future/ |title=Mysterious band of particles holds clues to Solar System's future |work=[[Cosmos (magazine)|Cosmos]] |first=Tony |last=Phillips |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=September 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161013210811/http://archive.cosmosmagazine.com/news/mysterious-band-particles-holds-clues-solar-systems-future/ |archivedate=October 13, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} It has also observed ENAs from the Earth's [[magnetosphere]]. In October 2010, significant changes were detected in the ribbon after six months, based on the second set of IBEX observations.{{cite news |url=http://www.astrobio.net/topic/solar-system/outer-solar-system/the-ever-changing-edge-of-the-solar-system/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140823162722/http://www.astrobio.net/topic/solar-system/outer-solar-system/the-ever-changing-edge-of-the-solar-system/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 23, 2014 |title=The Ever-Changing Edge of the Solar System |work=Astrobiology Magazine |date=October 2, 2010 |accessdate=November 8, 2010 }} It went on to detect neutral atoms from outside the Solar System, which were found to differ in composition from the Sun.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/ibex/news/nobowshock.html |title=IBEX Reveals a Missing Boundary At the Edge Of the Solar System |publisher=NASA |editor-first=Holly |editor-last=Zell |date=May 10, 2012}} Surprisingly, IBEX discovered that the heliosphere has no [[Bow shocks in astrophysics|bow shock]], and it measured its speed relative to the local [[interstellar medium]] (LISM) as {{convert|23.2|km/s|mph|abbr=on}}, improving on the previous measurement of {{convert|26.3|km/s|mph|abbr=on}} by ''[[Ulysses (spacecraft)|Ulysses]]''.{{cite news |url=https://astrobites.org/2012/05/14/no-shocks-for-this-bow-ibex-says-were-wrong/ |title=No Shocks for This Bow: IBEX Says We're Wrong |work=Astrobites |first=Susanna |last=Kohler |date=May 14, 2012 |accessdate=August 14, 2016}} Those speeds equate to 25% less pressure on the Sun's heliosphere than previously thought. In July 2013, IBEX results revealed a 4-lobed tail on the Solar System's heliosphere.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/nasa-s-ibex-provides-first-view-of-the-solar-system-s-tail/ |title=NASA's IBEX Provides First View Of the Solar System's Tail |publisher=NASA |first=Karen C. |last=Fox |date=July 10, 2013 |accessdate=August 13, 2015}} == Data transfer rate == Compared to other space observatories, IBEX has a low data transfer rate due to the limited requirements of the mission.{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/ibex/IBEXQandA.html |title=IBEX Q and A |publisher=NASA |date=July 25, 2008 |accessdate=May 14, 2015}} {{quote|... IBEX data transfer rates are slow compared with other telescopes due to the nature of the data it collects. IBEX does not need a "high speed" connection, since it only has the opportunity to collect up to a few particles per minute. Communication from the satellite to the ground is 20 times slower than a typical home cable modem (320,000 bits per second,) and from the ground to the satellite only 2,000 bits per second, which is 250 times slower! Once the signal is collected by the receivers on Earth it is carried over the internet to Mission Control Center in Dulles, VA and to the IBEX Science Operation Center in San Antonio, TX."|NASA's IBEX Q and A}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == Further reading == * {{cite conference |title=The Interstellar Boundary Explorer (IBEX) Mission |conference=Solar Wind 11 / SOHO 16—Connecting Sun and Heliosphere. June 12–17, 2005 |location= Whistler, British Columbia, Canada. |first1= D. |last1= McComas |first2= F. |last2= Allegrini |first3= L. |last3= Bartolone |first4= P. |last4= Bochsler |first5= M. |last5= Bzowski |display-authors= etal |date= Sep 2005 |bibcode= 2005ESASP.592..689M |isbn= 92-9092-903-0 |page= 689 |editor-first1= B. |editor-last1= Fleck |editor-first2= T.H. |editor-last2= Zurbuchen |editor-first3= H. |editor-last3= Lacoste }} == External links == {{Commons category|IBEX}} * {{Official website|http://ibex.swri.edu/}} * [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/missions/profile.cfm?MCode=IBEX IBEX Mission Profile] by [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/ NASA's Solar System Exploration] *{{YouTube|id=HtpR8TmZGW4|title=NASA Spacecraft Reveals Changes at Solar System's Edge}} {{Explorer program}} {{Orbital launches in 2008}} {{Space observatories}} {{Use American English|date=January 2014}} [[Category:Artificial satellites orbiting Earth]] [[Category:Astronomical surveys]] [[Category:Explorers program (NASA)]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2008]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by Pegasus rockets]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by air-launched rockets]]

{{Underlinked|date=June 2014}}
'''Jonathan "Jon" Levy''' is a behavior scientist, [[consultant]], writer, keynote speaker and media personality best known for his work in the fields of influence and adventure.<ref name=BusinessInsider-Influencers>{{cite web|last1=Feloni|first1=Richard|title=Amazing Things Happen At This Master Networker's New York Apartment|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/master-networker-jon-levy-party-2015-1#ixzz3Rxt5Wtf6|website=Business Insider|publisher=Business Insider Inc.|date=January 14, 2015 |accessdate=17 February 2015}}</ref><ref name=FastCompany>{{cite news|last1=Snow|first1=Shane|title=15 PEOPLE WHO ARE TAKING NETWORKING TO A NEW LEVEL|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3035568/hit-the-ground-running/the-dawn-of-the-superconnectors-20-people-who-are-taking-networking-t|accessdate=17 February 2015|publisher=Fast Company|date=September 20, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Men'sHealth-Party">{{cite news|last1=Levy|first1=Jon|title=Party Your Way to The Top|url=http://www.menshealth.com/best-life/influential-people|accessdate=17 February 2015|publisher=Men's Health Magazine|date=October 2014}}</ref> With the intention of bringing together exceptional people, Levy used his understanding of social interaction<ref name="ArtOfCharm_PodCast">{{cite podcast |url= http://theartofcharm.com/podcast/jon-levy-influencers-dinner-episode-351/|title= Jon Levy - The Influencers Dinner (Episode 351) |website= www.TheArtofCharm.com |publisher= The Art of Charm, Inc. |host= Jordan Harbinger |date= December 10, 2014 |time= |access-date= 17 February 2015}}</ref> to create [[Influencers Dinner|The Influencers Dinner]],<ref name="NY Times">{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Jennifer|title=Want to Meet Influential New Yorkers? Invite Them to Dinner|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/10/fashion/want-to-meet-influential-new-yorkers-invite-them-to-dinner.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=25 June 2014|publisher=The New York Times|date=October 9, 2013}}</ref> a secret dining experience for taste makers, thought leaders and influencers from different industries.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite news|last1=Porges|first1=Seth|title=Inside The Secretive Manhattan Dinner Party Where Deals Are Made|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/sethporges/2013/06/11/inside-the-secretive-manhattan-dinner-party-where-deals-are-made/|accessdate=25 June 2014|publisher=Forbes|date= June 11, 2013}}</ref><ref name="NY Observer">{{cite news|last1=Howe|first1=Alex|title=Dining Clubs Are the New Dinner Parties|url=http://observer.com/2013/11/dining-clubs-are-the-new-dinner-parties/|accessdate=25 June 2014|publisher=The New York Observer|date=2013-11-14}}</ref>
Jon’s work in human behavior has garnered him a reputation as one of the leading super connectors in America.<ref name=FastCompany /> His insights and strategies for effective social and professional interactions can be found in numerous media outlets including [[The New York Times]], [[Forbes]], [[Business Insider]], [[Inc. (magazine)|Inc]], and [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]].<ref name=BusinessInsider-Influencers /><ref name="Men'sHealth-Party" /><ref name=ArtOfCharm_PodCast /><ref name="NY Times" /><ref name=BusinessInsider-20Tips>{{cite news|last1=Feloni|first1=Richard|title=A Master Networker Shares His Top 20 Networking Tips|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/jon-levy-top-networking-tips-2015-1|accessdate=17 February 2015|publisher=Business Insider Inc.|date=January 27, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/author/jon-levy|title=Jon Levy's articles {{!}} Inc.com|website=www.inc.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}</ref>
== Scientific Research == Levy's research mostly focuses on what affects decision making.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.refinery29.com/2016/03/105242/dating-statistics|title=The 6 Signs That You're Compatible With An Online Match|last=MacMillen|first=Hayley|date=March 8, 2016|website=www.Refinery29.com|publisher=Refinery 29|access-date=November 22, 2016}}</ref> He is currently working out of [[Emagic|C Lab]] collaborating with [[Neuroscientist]] Dr. Moran Cerf, of [[Kellogg School of Management]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2016/11/new-york-social-gadfly-jon-levy-haunts-la-influencers-at-max-landis-halloween-party/|title=New York Social Gadfly Jon Levy Haunts LA Influencers at Max Landis’ Halloween Party|date=2016-11-02|newspaper=Observer|access-date=2016-11-23|language=en-US}}</ref> Levy spent years modeling the behavior of people at every level of influence, in order to better understand what causes them to engage and connect.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://theartofcharm.com/podcast-episodes/jon-levy-influencers-dinner-episode-351/|title=Jon Levy {{!}} The Influencers Dinner (Episode 351)|date=2014-12-10|work=The Art of Charm|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US}}</ref> His model's for engagement are what lead to the creation of The Influencers Dinner<ref name="NY Times" /> and Miror: The Salon<ref name="BusinessInsider-Influencers" />. Levy's most recent research relates to the dating statistics. His team anonymized over a billion data points, from the dating app Hinge, to discover what leads people to take their online connections and move them into in person relationships.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.refinery29.com/2016/03/105242/dating-statistics|title=The 6 Signs That You're Compatible With An Online Match|last=MacMillen|first=Hayley|access-date=2017-08-23}}</ref>
== Speaking & Thought Leadership == Levy has spoken and keynoted at many of the most respected conferences<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/jon-levy-influential-guests-dinner-parties-2018-10|title=How a master networker convinced execs, Olympians, and Nobel laureates to come to his house, cook him dinner, wash the dishes — and like it|work=Business Insider|access-date=2018-10-27}}</ref>, including [[TED (conference)|TED]] where he shared about "[https://www.ted.com/talks/jon_levy_what_makes_us_influential What Makes us Influential]"<ref>{{Citation|last=Levy|first=Jon|title=What makes us influential?|url=https://www.ted.com/talks/jon_levy_what_makes_us_influential|language=en|access-date=2018-10-27}}</ref>, PopTech where he presented "[https://vimeo.com/190292808 The Science of Adventure]"<ref>{{Citation|last=PopTech|title=The science of adventure|date=2016-11-04|url=https://vimeo.com/190292808|access-date=2018-10-27}}</ref>, [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune Magazine's]] Brainstorm Health on "[http://fortune.com/video/2017/05/03/jon-levy-adventure-the-2-am-principle/ How Adventure Can Save your life]"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/video/2017/05/03/jon-levy-adventure-the-2-am-principle/|title=Here's How Adventure Can Save Your Life|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}}</ref>, among others.
== The 2 AM Principle & The Science of Adventure == On November 8, 2016 Jon Levy's first book, ''[[The 2 AM Principle: Discover the Science of Adventure|The 2 AM Principle: Discover The Science of Adventure]]'' was published by [[Regan Arts]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reganarts.com/books/2016/the-2-am-principle/|title=The 2 AM Principle|website=Regan Arts.|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref> and distributed by [[Simon & Schuster]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://books.simonandschuster.com/The-2-AM-Principle/Jon-Levy/9781942872696|title=The 2 AM Principle|date=2016-11-08|isbn=9781942872696}}</ref> The book explores Levy's research on the science of adventure, emphasizing what he calls "[[The EPIC Model of Adventure]]",<ref>{{Cite book|title=The 2 AM Principle: Discover the Science of Adventure|last=Levy|first=Jon|date=2016-11-08|publisher=Regan Arts.|isbn=9781942872696|location=Place of publication not identified|language=English}}</ref> a four-stage process every adventure goes through.
In 2017, ''[[The 2 AM Principle: Discover the Science of Adventure|The 2 AM Principle]]'' won 1st place for book design at the annual [[New York Book Show]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reganarts.com/spill/2017/07/regan-arts-award-winning-design-production/|title=Regan Arts Award-Winning Design & Production|work=Regan Arts.|access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref>
== Personal life == Between 2014 and 2015, Levy was recognized as both one of “New York's Most Successful Bachelors” by [[Gotham Magazine]]<ref name="GothamMagazine-Bachelor">{{cite news|url=http://gotham-magazine.com/personalities/articles/get-to-know-new-yorks-most-successful-bachelors|title=New York's Most Successful Bachelors|last1=GAFFNEY|first1=ADRIENNE|date=October 2014|accessdate=17 February 2015|publisher=Gotham Magazine|issue=2014 ISSUE 6}}</ref> and one of the “41 Most Eligible Bachelors" in America by [[Elle Magazine]].<ref name="Elle-Bachelors">{{cite news|url=http://www.elle.com/life-love/sex-relationships/reviews/g25713/elles-most-eligible-bachelors/?slide=26|title=MEET ELLE.COM'S 41 MOST ELIGIBLE BACHELORS|last1=Friedman|first1=Katie|date=February 2015|accessdate=17 February 2015|publisher=Elle}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} In [[mathematical logic]] and [[computer science]], the '''Kleene star''' (or '''Kleene operator''' or '''Kleene closure''') is a [[unary operation]], either on [[Set (mathematics)|sets]] of [[string (computer science)|strings]] or on sets of symbols or characters. In mathematics it is more commonly known as the [[free monoid]] construction. The application of the Kleene star to a set ''V'' is written as ''V''<sup>*</sup>. It is widely used for [[regular expression]]s, which is the context in which it was introduced by [[Stephen Kleene]] to characterize certain [[Automata theory|automata]], where it means "zero or more".
# If ''V'' is a set of strings, then ''V''<sup>*</sup> is defined as the smallest [[superset]] of ''V'' that contains the [[empty string]] ε and is [[Closure (mathematics)|closed]] under the [[concatenation|string concatenation operation]]. # If ''V'' is a set of symbols or characters, then ''V''<sup>*</sup> is the set of all strings over symbols in ''V'', including the empty string ε.
The set ''V''<sup>*</sup> can also be described as the set of finite-length strings that can be generated by concatenating arbitrary elements of ''V'', allowing the use of the same element multiple times. If ''V'' is either the [[empty set]] ∅ or the singleton set {ε}, then ''V''<sup>*</sup> = {ε}; if ''V'' is any other [[finite set]], then ''V''<sup>*</sup> is a [[countably infinite set]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Nayuki Minase |date=10 May 2011 |title=Countable sets and Kleene star |work=Project Nayuki |url=http://www.nayuki.io/page/countable-sets-and-kleene-star |accessdate=11 January 2012}}</ref>
The operators are used in [[rewrite rule]]s for [[generative grammar]]s.
== Definition and notation == Given a set ''V'' define :''V''<sub>0</sub> = {ε} (the language consisting only of the empty string), :''V''<sub>1</sub> = ''V'' and define recursively the set :''V''<sub>''i''+1</sub> = { ''wv'' : ''w'' ∈ ''V''<sub>''i''</sub> and ''v'' ∈ ''V'' } for each ''i''>0.
If ''V'' is a formal language, then ''V''<sub>''i''</sub>, the ''i''-th power of the set ''V'', is a shorthand for the [[Concatenation#Concatenation of sets of strings|concatenation]] of set ''V'' with itself ''i'' times. That is, ''V''<sub>''i''</sub> can be understood to be the set of all [[string (computer science)|strings]] that can be represented as the concatenation of ''i'' strings in ''V''.
The definition of Kleene star on ''V'' is<ref>{{cite book |last1=Ebbinghaus |first1=Heinz-Dieter |authorlink1=Heinz-Dieter Ebbinghaus |last2=Flum |first2=Jörg |last3=Thomas |first3=Wolfgang |doi= |date=1994 |title=Mathematical Logic |edition=2nd |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] |location=[[New York City|New York]] |isbn=0-387-94258-0 |page=656 |url=https://www.springer.com/mathematics/book/978-0-387-94258-2 |quote=The '''Kleene closure''' ''L''<sup>*</sup> of ''L'' is defined to be <math>\sideset{}{_{i=0}^\infty}\bigcup L^i</math>.}}</ref> :<math> V^*=\bigcup_{i \geq 0 }V_i = V_0 \cup V_1 \cup V_2 \cup V_3 \cup V_4 \cup \ldots.</math>
Notice that the Kleene star operator is an idempotent unary operator: (''V''<sup>*</sup>)<sup>*</sup> = ''V''<sup>*</sup> for any set ''V'' of strings or characters.
== Kleene plus == In some [[formal language]] studies, (e.g. [[Abstract family of languages|AFL theory]]) a variation on the Kleene star operation called the ''Kleene plus'' is used. The Kleene plus omits the ''V''<sub>0</sub> term in the above union. In other words, the Kleene plus on ''V'' is
:<math>V^+=\bigcup_{i \geq 1} V_i = V_1 \cup V_2 \cup V_3 \cup \ldots.</math>
For every set ''L'', the Kleene plus of ''L'' (denoting ''L''<sup>+</sup>) equals the concatenation of ''L'' with ''L''<sup>*</sup>; this holds because every element of ''L''<sup>+</sup> must either be composed from one element of ''L'' and finitely many non-empty terms in ''L'' or is just an element of ''L'' (where ''L'' itself is retrieved by taking ''L'' concatenated with ε). Conversely, ''L''<sup>*</sup> = {ε} ∪ ''L''<sup>+</sup>.
== Examples == Example of Kleene star applied to set of strings: : {"ab","c"}<sup>*</sup> = { ε, "ab", "c", "abab", "abc", "cab", "cc", "ababab", "ababc", "abcab", "abcc", "cabab", "cabc", "ccab", "ccc", ...}.
Example of Kleene plus applied to set of characters: : {"a", "b", "c"}<sup>+</sup> = { "a", "b", "c", "aa", "ab", "ac", "ba", "bb", "bc", "ca", "cb", "cc", "aaa", "aab", ...}. Kleene star applied to the same character set: : {"a", "b", "c"}<sup>*</sup> = { ε, "a", "b", "c", "aa", "ab", "ac", "ba", "bb", "bc", "ca", "cb", "cc", "aaa", "aab", ...}.
Example of Kleene star applied to the empty set: :∅<sup>*</sup> = {ε}.
Example of Kleene plus applied to the empty set: :∅<sup>+</sup> = ∅ ∅<sup>*</sup> = { } = ∅, where concatenation is an [[associative]] and [[noncommutative]] product, sharing these properties with the [[Cartesian product]] of sets.
Example of Kleene plus and Kleene star applied to the singleton set containing the empty string: :If V = {ε}, then also ''V''<sub>''i''</sub> = {ε} for each ''i'', hence V<sup>*</sup> = V<sup>+</sup> = {ε}.
== Generalization ==
Strings form a [[monoid]] with concatenation as the binary operation and ε the identity element. The Kleene star is defined for any monoid, not just strings. More precisely, let (''M'', ⋅) be a monoid, and ''S'' ⊆ ''M''. Then ''S''<sup>*</sup> is the smallest submonoid of ''M'' containing ''S''; that is, ''S''<sup>*</sup> contains the neutral element of ''M'', the set ''S'', and is such that if ''x'',''y'' ∈ ''S''<sup>*</sup>, then ''x''⋅''y'' ∈ ''S''<sup>*</sup>.
Furthermore, the Kleene star is generalized by including the *-operation (and the union) in the [[algebraic structure]] itself by the notion of [[complete star semiring]].<Ref name="droste">{{cite book |last1=Droste |first1=M. |last2=Kuich |first2=W. |date=2009 |title=Handbook of Weighted Automata |chapter=Chapter 1: Semirings and Formal Power Series |series=Monographs in Theoretical Computer Science |publisher=Springer |doi=10.1007/978-3-642-01492-5_1 |isbn=978-3-642-01491-8 |page=9}}</ref>

Numerous species placed in ''Albizia'' by early authors were eventually moved to other genera, particularly ''[[Archidendron]]'' and many other [[Ingeae]], as well as certain [[Acacieae]], [[Mimoseae]], and even [[Caesalpinioideae]] and [[Faboideae]].ILDIS (2005) The delimitation of ''[[Falcataria]]'' and ''[[Pithecellobium]]'' - close relatives of ''Albizia'' - is notoriously complex, with species having been moved between the genera time and again, and probably will continue to do so. Other closely related genera like ''[[Chloroleucon]]'' and ''[[Samanea]]'' are often merged with ''Albizia'' entirely. {{Compact ToC |center =yes |num=yes}} ==A== * ''[[Albizia acle]]'' (syn. [[File:Malta - Naxxar - Triq il-Markiz Scicluna - Palazzo Parisio 02 ies.jpg|thumb|right|Grandi Giardini Italiani sign at [[Palazzo Parisio (Naxxar)|Palazzo Parisio & Gardens]] in [[Naxxar]], [[Malta]].]] The '''Grandi Giardini Italiani''' is an association of major [[garden]]s in [[Italy]] and [[Malta]]. Its members include some of the most important gardens in Italy and Malta.
== List of member gardens == * [[Fondazione Pompeo Mariani]] (Imperia) * [[Giardini Botanici di Stigliano]] (Roma) * [[Giardini Botanici di Villa Taranto]] (Verbania) * [[Giardini Botanici Hanbury]] Parisio|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150721000528/http://www.palazzoparisio.com/house-garden/the-gardens/grandi-giardini-italiani|archivedate=21 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Palazzo Patrizi]] page.title: List of Superfund sites in Georgia (U.S. state)

revision.text:
This is a '''list of Superfund sites in Georgia''' designated under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) environmental law. The CERCLA federal law of 1980 authorized the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) to create a list of [[Pollution|polluted]] locations requiring a long-term response to clean up hazardous material contaminations.P.L. 96-510, {{USC|42|9601|9675}}), December 11, 1980. These locations are known as [[Superfund]] sites, and are placed on the [[National Priorities List]] (NPL). The NPL guides the EPA in "determining which sites warrant further investigation" for [[environmental remediation]]. As of November 13, 2014, there were 16 Superfund sites on the National Priorities List in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].{{cite web| url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/npl/ |title=National Priorities List |publisher=United States Enivironmental Protection Agency |accessdate=November 13, 2014}} One additional site has been proposed for entry on the list. Five sites have been cleaned up and removed from the list. ==Superfund sites== :{{legend2|#fcf75e|Proposed for addition to National Priorities List|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} :{{legend2|#d0f0c0|Deleted from National Priorities List|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !CERCLIS ID!!Name!!County!!Reason!!Proposed!!Listed!!Construction

The following is a partial listing of '''[[Tree City USA|Tree Cities USA]]'''. To be a Tree City, the community must meet four standards set by the [[National Arbor Day Foundation]] and the [[National Association of State Foresters]]: # The community must have a tree board or department. # The community must have established a community ordinance for tree care. # There must be a community forestry program with an annual budget of at least $2 per capita. # The community must have an Arbor Day observance and proclamation.

revision.text:
This is a partial '''list of newsgroups''' that are significant for their popularity or their position in [[Usenet]] history.
==The Big 8 hierarchies== These are the most widely distributed and carefully controlled newsgroup hierarchies. See [[Big 8 (Usenet)]] and the [[Great Renaming]] for more information.
===comp=== {{See also|comp.* hierarchy}} [[Computer]]-related topics.
===humanities=== Topics related to the [[humanities]] (fine arts, literature, philosophy, [[Classical Latin]], etc.).
===misc=== Miscellaneous topics. Examples include:
* misc.legal.moderated — A moderated legal forum. * ''[[misc.taxes.moderated]]'' — A moderated professional tax forum open to the general public. *
===news=== Matters related to the functioning of [[Usenet]] itself. Examples include:
*''[[news.admin.net-abuse.blocklisting]]'' — discussion related to the use of blocklists to deal with spam and other unwanted network traffic. *''[[news.admin.net-abuse.email]]'' — discussion of abuse of email by spammers and other parties.
=== rec ===
[[Recreation]] and [[entertainment]] topics. Examples include:
* ''[[rec.arts.movies.current-films]]''—The latest [[movie]] releases. * ''[[rec.arts.movies.past-films]]''—Past films. * ''[[rec.arts.poems]] * ''[[rec.arts.sf.tv]]''—Discussing general television SF (i.e. [[science-fiction]], or "[[speculative fiction]]"). * ''[[rec.arts.sf.tv.babylon5.moderated]]''—discussion of ''[[Babylon 5]]'' and other projects of [[J. Michael Straczynski]]. * ''[[rec.arts.tv]]''—Television, its history, and past and current shows, i.e. the main [[television]] newsgroup. * ''[[rec.arts.tv.soaps.cbs]]''—discussion about soap operas broadcast by the [[CBS]] television network. * ''[[rec.arts.tv.mst3k.misc]]''—discussion of the TV series ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000#Fandom|Mystery Science Theater 3000]]''. * ''[[rec.arts.tv.x-factor]]''—General discussion of the X-Factor tv show and all its worldwide editions. * ''[[rec.food.cooking]]''—"discussion of cooking in general. Recipes and requests for recipes are welcome here, as are discussions of cooking techniques, equipment, etc."<ref>{{citation |first=Victor |last=Sack |title=rec.food.cooking FAQ and conversion file |at=sec. 9.1 |url=http://vsack.homepage.t-online.de/rfc_faq0.html#9.1 |date=20 October 2016}}</ref> * ''[[rec.humor.oracle]]''—[[Internet humor]] * ''[[rec.sport.cricket]]''—general discussion of world cricket. * ''rec.sport.soccer''—general discussion of world football (soccer). * ''[[rec.woodworking]]''—general discussion of woodworking.
===sci=== {{See also|sci.* hierarchy}} [[Science]]-related topics. *Sci.bio.* **[news:sci.bio.paleontology sci.bio.paleontology] **[news:sci.bio.evolution sci.bio.evolution] *[news:sci.skeptic sci.skeptic]
===soc=== Discussion related to [[society]] and social [[subculture]]s. Examples include:
* ''[[soc.culture.usa]]''— for the discussion of culture in the USA. * ''[[soc.culture.iraq]]''— for the discussion of [[Iraq]]. * ''[[soc.genealogy]]''— for the discussion of [[genealogy]]. * ''[[soc.motss]]''— for the discussion of gay and lesbian issues.<ref>{{cite web|title=The First Gay Space on the Internet|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/bitwise/2014/08/online_gay_culture_and_soc_motss_how_a_usenet_group_anticipated_how_we_use.html | |first=David |last=Auerbach | date=August 20, 2014|accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref> * ''[[soc.org.nonprofit]]''— for the discussion of [[nonprofit]] organization management issues.<ref>{{cite book |title=Fundraising For Dummies |first=John |last=Mutz |date=2010 |isbn=978-0-7645-9847-0|publisher=John Wiley & Sons }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=A Brief Review of the Early History of Nonprofits and the Internet (before 1996) |url=http://www.coyotecommunications.com/tech/npo_and_net_history.shtml |first=Jayne |last=Cravens | accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref> * ''[[soc.org.service—clubs.misc]]''— for the discussion of service clubs such as [[Kiwanis]], [[Lions International|Lions]], [[Rotary International]], [[Civitan International]] and [[Optimist International|Optimists]]. * ''[[soc.penpals]]''— to find penpals * ''[[soc.politics]]''— for the discussion of [[politics]] * ''[[soc.religion.bahai]]''— for the discussion of [[Bahai]] * ''[[soc.religion.christian]]''— for the discussion of [[Christianity]] * ''[[soc.rights-human]]''— for the discussion of [[human rights]]<ref>{{cite book |title=Cybermarketing |first=Pauline |last=Bickerton |date=2007 |isbn=0 7506 4704 3 |publisher=Taylor & Francis }}</ref>
===talk=== Discussion of various topics, especially controversial ones. Includes political topics as well. Examples include:
*''[[talk.bizarre]]'' — a newsgroup for experiencing the bizarre. *''[[talk.origins]]'' — [[evolution]]-[[creationism]] controversy which maintains an extensive FAQ.
==The alt hierarchy== {{See also|alt.* hierarchy}} This is the most extensive newsgroup hierarchy outside of the Big 8. Examples include:
*''[[alt.2600]]'' — Official group for [[2600: The Hacker Quarterly]] *''[[Alt.Adoption]]'' — for [[adoption]] *''[[alt.arts.poetry.comments]]'' — for poetry and [[poetry critique]] *''[[alt.asian-movies]]'' — for discussions focusing mainly on Hong Kong action cinema. *''[[alt.atheism]]'' — discusses [[atheism]] *''[[alt.binaries.boneless]]'' *''[[alt.binaries.slack]]'' — artwork created by and for the [[Church of the SubGenius]]. *''[[alt.callahans]]'' — [[Spider Robinson]]'s Callahan's Place online *''[[alt.config]]'' — creation of new newsgroups in the ''[[Alt hierarchy|alt.*'' hierarchy]]''. *''[[alt.digitiser]]'' — discussion of the video games magazine ''[[Digitiser]]''. *''[[alt.fan]]'' — [[fandom]] discussions. *''[[alt.gothic]]'' — a gothic newsgroup and birthplace of [[Convergence (goth festival)|Convergence]] *''[[alt.horology]]'' This Internet newsgroup concerns all aspects of [[horology]] (the [[science]] of [[time]] and [[timekeeping]], [[clocks]] and [[watches]]). Those posting to it range from novices to collectors to professional [[watchmakers]] & [[clockmakers]]. *''[[alt.religion.kibology]]'' — He who Greps. *''[[alt.sex]]'' — the first ''alt.*'' newsgroup for discussion of sexual topics. *''[[alt.sex.bondage]]'' — discussion of [[BDSM]] sex. *''[[alt.sex.cancel]]'' — set up specifically as a means of defeating newsgroup spam cross-posted to the entire alt.sex hierarchy *''[[alt.sex.stories]]'' — text-based erotic stories of all types. *''[[alt.slack]]'' — Posting relating to the [[Church of the Subgenius]]. *''[[alt.suicide.holiday]]'' — pro-choice discussion of [[suicide]]. *''[[alt.sysadmin.recovery]]'' — the Scary Devil Monastery. *''[[alt.tasteless]]'' — discussion of subject matter in too poor taste to be discussed elsewhere. *''[[alt.tv.simpsons]]'' — discusses the TV show ''[[The Simpsons]].'' *''[[alt.usage.english]]'' — discussion of English words, grammar, etymology *''[[alt.usenet.kooks]]'' — discussion of Usenet [[crank (person)|kook]]s and their idiosyncratic theories. *''[[alt.zines]]'' — discussion of small-press publications, magazines, and pamphlets ([[zine]]s).
==Other newsgroups== These newsgroups fall outside of the official [[Big 8 (Usenet)|Big 8 hierarchies]], as well as the less formal [[alt.* hierarchy|''alt'' hierarchy]]. Other newsgroups can consist of geographic regions (official or unofficial), corporations, and other institutions or groups.
==References== <references />
{{Usenetnav}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Newsgroups}} [[Category:Newsgroups| ]] [[Category:Internet-related lists|newsgroups]]

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=November 2013}} The following is a list of things named after Hungarian physicist [[Eugene Wigner|E. P. Wigner]].
==Physics== * [[Bargmann–Wigner equations]] *[[Jordan–Wigner transformation]] *[[Newton–Wigner localization]] *[[Polynomial Wigner–Ville distribution]] *[[Relativistic Breit–Wigner distribution]] *[[Thomas–Wigner rotation]] *[[Wigner–d'Espagnat inequality]] *[[Wigner–Eckart theorem]] *[[Wigner–Inonu contraction]] *[[Wigner–Seitz cell]] *[[Wigner–Seitz radius]] *[[Wigner–Weyl transform]] *[[Wigner–Wilkins spectrum]] *[[Wigner's classification]] *{{nowrap|[[Wigner quasi-probability distribution]]}} *[[Wigner's friend]] *[[Wigner's theorem]] *[[Wigner crystal]] *[[Wigner D-matrix]] *[[Wigner effect]] *[[Wigner energy]] * [[Wigner lattice]] * Wigner poisoning, [[Xe-135]] "poisoning" in nuclear reactors poisoning. * Wigner rotation, see [[Thomas–Wigner rotation]]
==Mathematics== *[[Gabor–Wigner transform]] *{{nowrap|[[Modified Wigner distribution function]]}} *[[Wigner distribution function]] *[[Wigner semicircle distribution]] *[[Wigner surmise]]
==Other== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130616125709/http://wigner.mta.hu/index_e.php Wigner Research Centre for Physics] in Budapest, which houses the [http://wigner.mta.hu/wignerdc Wigner Data Center]. *[http://www.ans.org/honors/va-wigner Eugene P. Wigner Reactor Physicist Award] at the [[American Nuclear Society]]. *[http://www.ornl.gov/adm/wigner_fellowship/ Wigner Fellowship Program] at [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] (ORNL). *[http://www.itp.tu-berlin.de/grk1558/events/eugene-wigner-colloquium Eugene-Wigner-Colloquium] at the Institut für Theoretische Physik of [[Technische Universität Berlin]]. *[https://www.mydesk.tu-berlin.de/campusuebersicht/gebaeude/1483.html Eugene-Paul-Wigner-Building] at [[Technische Universität Berlin]]. *The Eugene P. Wigner Auditorium at [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]]<ref>[http://www.ornl.gov/ornlhome/print/press_release_print.cfm?ReleaseNumber=mr19960111-01 "Auditorium at ORNL Renamed in Honor of Eugene P. Wigner"] ORNL Press Release, (Jan. 11, 1996).</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Lists of things named after physicists|w]]

revision.comment: Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/93.41.1.49|93.41.1.49]] ([[User talk:93.41.1.49|talk]]): Not an improvement. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
The '''Los Angeles School''' of Urbanism is an academic movement which emerged during the mid-1980s, loosely based at [[UCLA]] and the [[University of Southern California]], which centers urban analysis on [[Los Angeles, California]].
==History== The first published identification of the Los Angeles (L.A.) School as such was by [[Mike Davis (scholar)|Mike Davis]] in his popular urban history of Los Angeles, ''[[City of Quartz]]'' (1990).<ref>{{cite book | first=Mike | last=Davis| pages=84| year=1990 | publisher=Verso | isbn= 978-1-84467-568-5 | nopp=true | title= City of Quartz: Excavating the Future in Los Angeles}}</ref> According to Davis, the school emerged informally during the mid-1980s when an eclectic variety of [[neo-Marxist]] scholars began publishing a series of articles and books dealing exclusively with Los Angeles. During the school’s formation, Davis cautiously estimated that the school had about twenty members scattered throughout [[Southern California]] and beyond, with some members purportedly residing as far away as [[Frankfurt, Germany]].<ref>Dear, Michael J (2002). "The Resistible Rise of the L.A. School" pp3-16 in Dear, Michael J. (ed.)''From Chicago to L.A.: Making Sense of Urban Theory''. Sage Publications.</ref> Much of the work published by L.A. School members during the 1980s and early 1990s garnered considerable attention. However, while some members (e.g. [[Edward Soja]] and Mike Davis) became household names in urban theory, there was little consciousness of the school as its own entity, especially outside of Los Angeles. This changed in 1998, with the publication of an article by [[Michael J. Dear]] and Steven Flusty, which explicitly argued for the existence of a distinct L.A. School of Urbanism, of which its various theories, concepts, and empirical works could be pooled together to constitute a radical new conception of ‘postmodern urbanism.’<ref>Dear, Michael J. and Flusty, Steven (2000). “Postmodern Urbanism.” ''Annals of the Association of American Geographers.'' '''90'''(1): 50-72</ref> After Dear and Flusty’s publication, Dear popularized the school<ref>{{cite book | first=Edward | last=Soja| year=2010 | publisher=University of Minnesota Press | isbn= 978-0-8166-6668-3| nopp=true | title= ''Seeking Spatial Justice'', pps.173-175}}</ref> through the production of a series of articles and books, including a full-length edited volume comparing the L.A. School to the Chicago School.<ref>Dear, Michael J. (ed.); 2002; ''From Chicago to L.A.: Making Sense of Urban Theory''; Sage Publications</ref> Though much of the work of the L.A. School is still widely read in urban studies, the school’s membership has declined substantially in recent years. At a retirement party for Soja in 2008 at which many purported members were present, only Michael J. Dear appeared to be willing to envisage the school’s continued existence. This situation reflects the vital conceptual disagreements between members of the LA School, and especially between Dear and the other members.<ref name="Halle">{{cite journal|last=Halle|first=David|author2=Beveridge, Andrew |title=Changing Cities and Directions: New York and Los Angeles|journal=On-Line Working Paper Series, California Center for Population Research, UC Los Angeles|date=12-01-2008}}</ref>
==Members== There is no official list of present or historic members of the Los Angeles School of Urbanism. Some thinkers who are commonly considered members include: *[[Michael Dear]] *[[Mike Davis (scholar)|Mike Davis]] *[[Allen J Scott]] *[[Edward Soja]] *[[Michael Storper]] *[[Jennifer Wolch]]
==Ideas== The L.A. School has no official doctrine, and there is great diversity in the works of its various members. Nevertheless, there are several influences, themes, and concepts which are relatively consistent in the school’s scholarship. Perhaps the central characteristic of the thought of the L.A. School is a sustained focus on Los Angeles in both empirical and theoretical work, often with the underlying claim that L.A. is the paradigmatic American metropolis of the 20th and 21st centuries.<ref name="Curry ">{{cite journal|last=Curry|first=James|author2=Kenney, Martin |title=The Paradigmatic City: Postindustrial Illusion and the Los Angeles School|journal=Antipode|year=1999| volume=31|issue=1|pages=1–28|doi=10.1111/1467-8330.00089}}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal | author = Monahan, Torin. | year = 2002 | title = Los Angeles Studies: The Emergence of a Specialty Field | journal = City & Society | volume = 14 | issue = 2 | pages = 155–184 | url = http://publicsurveillance.com/papers/LA_Studies.pdf | format = pdf | doi=10.1525/city.2002.14.2.155}}</ref> More than this, the L.A. School poses a challenge to, what many members see as, the dominant [[Chicago school (sociology)|Chicago School]] of Urbanism.<ref>Dear, Michael J and Dahmann, Nicolas (2008). “Urban Politics and the Los Angeles School of Urbanism.” ''Urban Affairs Review.'' '''44'''(2): 266-279</ref> While the Chicago School presents a [[modernist]] theory of cities as based on social darwinist struggles for urban space, the Los Angeles School proposes a [[postmodern]] or [[postfordist]] vision. While not all members of the L.A. School identify as postmodernists, and in fact some (e.g. Mike Davis)<ref>Davis, Mike (1985). “Urban Renaissance and the Spirit of Postmodernism” New Left Review. I/151</ref> are against the very concept, a focus on [[postmodernism]] is fundamental to many members of the L.A. School, who rely heavily upon theorists associated with postmodernism, such as [[Baudrillard]], [[Michel Foucault|Foucault]], [[Frederic Jameson|Jameson]], and [[Derrida]].<ref>{{cite book | first=Edward | last=Soja| year=1990 | publisher=Verso | isbn= 0-86091-936-6 | nopp=true | title= Postmodern Geographies: The Reassertion of Space in Critical Social Theory}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | first=Michael J. | last=Dear| year=2001 | publisher=Blackwell | isbn= 0-631-20988-3 | nopp=true | title= The Postmodern Urban Condition }}</ref> A further stream of work emerging from the LA School is represented by Scott and Storper's many publications on flexible specialization, agglomeration, and the economic dynamics of the contemporary metropolis. Scott and Storper's work differs from that of Dear and Soja by approaching urban theory from the perspective of [[postfordism]] rather than postmodernism. Scott and Storper represent one distinctive tendency in the LA School; Dear and Soja represent another.
==Criticism== A number of criticisms have been raised against the Los Angeles School. Perhaps the most important of these is skepticism over the school’s actual importance relative to its claims. For instance, one criticism is that its literature sometimes deceptively excludes discussions or citations of other important works on urban issues, to give readers the impression that the L.A. school is more radical, original, and important than it actually is. In particular, some critics think that the contemporary importance of the Chicago School is grossly overstated by L.A. theorists, and that little to no attention is allocated to extremely important scholarly materials produced in the period between the decline of the Chicago School and the emergence of the L.A. School, particularly the work of Marxist urban theorists like [[Manuel Castells]], [[David Harvey (geographer)|David Harvey]], and [[Henri Lefebvre]].<ref>Gottdiener, Mark.; Urban Analysis as Merchandising: The ‘LA School’ and the Understanding of Metropolitan Development’ pp157-181 in Eade, John and Mele, Christopher (eds.) (2008). ''Urban Analysis as Merchandising: The “LA School” and the Understanding of Metropolitan Development''. Blackwell Publishers</ref> On a similar vein, much of the work of the L.A. School has been criticized for its incoherence and lack of a demonstrable methodology.<ref>Sui, Daniel Z (1999). Postmodern Urbanism Disrobed: or Why Postmodern Urbanism is a Dead End for Urban Geography. ''Urban Geography'' '''20'''(5): 403-411.</ref> A final criticism questions the L.A. School’s fundamental claim that Los Angeles should be considered the paradigmatic postmodern American city. This stems both from external comparisons which have been made between Los Angeles and other cities,<ref>Nijman, Jan (2000). The Paradigmatic City. ''Annals of the Association of American Geographers'' '''90'''(1): 135-145.</ref><ref>Bacon, Nicholas A (2010).“Lost in Dialectic: A Critical Introduction to Urban Space in Greater Hartford, 1633-2010.” Undergraduate Honors Thesis, Trinity College, CT. {{cite web |url=https://www.trincoll.edu/NR/rdonlyres/5D63F612-3C18-4A87-AAAB-1290D1FF0308/0/Bacon_Dialectic.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528143853/http://www.trincoll.edu/NR/rdonlyres/5D63F612-3C18-4A87-AAAB-1290D1FF0308/0/Bacon_Dialectic.pdf |archivedate=2010-05-28 |df= }} pp.32-55.</ref> and findings that in certain cases urban phenomena in Los Angeles do not match those of other American cities.<ref>{{cite book | first=Jason | last=Hackworth| year=2006 | publisher=Cornell University Press | isbn= 978-0-8014-7303-6| nopp=true | title= ''The Neoliberal City'', p.81}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Post-Fordism]] *[[Globalization]] *[[Urban structure]] *[[Urban theory]] *[[Urbanism]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090526211754/https://college.usc.edu/la_school/ LA School of Urbanism] at University of Southern California
[[Category:Urban geography]] [[Category:Urban planning]]

'''Ocean deoxygenation''' is the expansion of [[oxygen minimum zone]]s in the world's [[oceans]] as a consequence of [[carbon emissions|anthropogenic emissions of carbon dioxide]].{{ref|stramma}}{{ref|Mora}} The change has been fairly rapid and poses a threat to fish and other types of marine life, as well as to people who depend on marine life for nutrition or livelihood.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jan/04/oceans-suffocating-dead-zones-oxygen-starved Oceans suffocating as huge dead zones quadruple since 1950, scientists warn] The Guardian, 2018</ref>
Oceanographers and others have discussed what phrase best describes the phenomenon to non-specialists. Among the options considered have been '''ocean suffocation''' (which was used in a news report from May 2008{{ref|deadzone}}), "ocean oxygen deprivation",{{ref|name}} "decline in ocean oxygen", "marine deoxygenation", "ocean oxygen depletion" and "ocean [[Hypoxia (environmental)|hypoxia]]".
==Implications== Ocean deoxygenation poses implications for [[Primary production|ocean productivity]], nutrient cycling, [[carbon cycling]], and [[marine habitats]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/scientists-say-oceans-are-rapidly-losing-oxygen/3313942.html|title=Scientists: Oceans Rapidly Losing Oxygen|first=George|last=Putic|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://weather.com/science/environment/news/global-warming-starving-west-coast-waters-of-oxygen|title=Global Warming Is Starving West Coast Waters of Oxygen|publisher=}}</ref>
Most of the excess heat from CO<sub>2</sub> and other greenhouse gas emissions is absorbed by the oceans.<ref>Levitus, Sydney, et al. "Warming of the world ocean." Science 287.5461 (2000): 2225–2229</ref> Warmer oceans cause deoxygenation both because oxygen is less soluble in warmer water,<ref>https://www.ysi.com/File%20Library/Documents/Technical%20Notes/DO-Oxygen-Solubility-Table.pdf</ref> and through temperature driven stratification of the ocean which inhibits the production of oxygen from photosynthesis.<ref>"Climate-driven trends in contemporary ocean productivity." Nature 444.7120 (2006): 752–755</ref>
The ocean surface stratifies as the atmosphere and ocean warms causing ice melt and glacial runoff. This results in a less salty and therefore a less dense layer that floats on top.<ref>Sigman, Daniel M., Samuel L. Jaccard, and Gerald H. Haug. "Polar ocean stratification in a cold climate." Nature 428.6978 (2004): 59–63</ref> Also the warmer waters themselves are less dense. This stratification inhibits the upwelling of nutrients (the ocean constantly recycles its nutrients) into the upper layer of the ocean.<ref>Arrigo, Kevin R., et al. "Phytoplankton community structure and the drawdown of nutrients and CO 2 in the Southern Ocean." Science 283.5400 (1999): 365–367. Behrenfeld, Michael J., et al. "Climate-driven trends in contemporary ocean productivity." Nature 444.7120 (2006): 752–755</ref> This is where the majority of oceanic photosynthesis (such as by phytoplankton) occurs.<ref>Cermeño, Pedro, et al. "The role of nutricline depth in regulating the ocean carbon cycle." Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 105.51 (2008): 20344-20349</ref> This decrease in nutrient supply is likely to decrease rates of photosynthesis in the surface ocean, which is responsible for approximately half of the oxygen produced globally.<ref>Cermeño, Pedro, et al. "The role of nutricline depth in regulating the ocean carbon cycle." Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 105.51 (2008): 20344-20349</ref> Increased stratification can also decrease the supply of oxygen to the interior of the ocean. Warmer waters also increase the metabolism of marine organisms,<ref>Gillooly, James F., et al. "Effects of size and temperature on metabolic rate." science 293.5538 (2001): 2248–2251</ref> leading to increased respiration rates. In the surface ocean, increased respiration will likely lead to lower net oxygen production, and thus less oxygen transferred to the atmosphere. In the interior ocean, the combination of increased respiration and decreased oxygen supply from surface waters can draw oxygen down to hypoxic or anoxic levels. Not only are low levels of oxygen lethal to fish and other upper trophic level species, they can change the microbially mediated cycling of globally important elements such as nitrogen; nitrate replaces oxygen as the primary microbial electron acceptor at very low oxygen concentrations. All this, increased demand on herbivores, decreased nutrient supply, decreased dissolved oxygen, etc., result in catastrophic food web mismatches.<ref>Nagelkerken Global alteration of ocean ecosystem functioning due to increasing human CO2 emissions, PNAS vol. 112 no. 43, 2015</ref><ref>Goldenberg, Silvan U., et al. "Boosted food web productivity through ocean acidification collapses under warming." Global Change Biology (2017)</ref>
Ocean model simulations predict a decline of up to 7% in the global ocean O<sub>2</sub> content over the next hundred years. The decline of [[oxygen]] is projected to continue for a thousand years or more.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Annual Review of Marine Science|volume=2|pages=199–229|doi=10.1146/annurev.marine.010908.163855|pmid=21141663|year=2010|authors=Ralph F. Keeling, Arne Kortzinger, Nicolas Gruber|title=Ocean Deoxygenation in a Warming World|url=http://eprints.uni-kiel.de/8673/1/annurev.marine.010908.pdf|bibcode=2010ARMS....2..199K|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301225657/http://eprints.uni-kiel.de/8673/1/annurev.marine.010908.pdf|archivedate=2016-03-01|df=}}</ref>
