Its users no longer have to wait for anything."<ref>{{cite web|url = https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2017/11/ubuntu-17-10-return-of-the-gnome/|title = Ubuntu 17.10: Return of the GNOME|accessdate = 2 December 2017|last =Gilbertson |first = Scott|work = [[Ars Technica]] |date = 27 November 2017}}</ref>
The first point release, 17.10.1, was released on 12 January 2018. It fixed a problem that caused the firmware of some [[Lenovo]] computers to not boot.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fossbytes.com/ubuntu-17-10-1-download-iso-torrent-bios-fix/|title=Ubuntu 17.10.1 Linux Distro Now Available — Download ISO Files And Torrents For All Official Flavors|website=''fossbytes.com''|accessdate = 19 January 2018}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (Bionic Beaver)=== [[File:Ubuntu 18.04.png|thumb|Ubuntu 18.04 LTS ''Bionic Beaver'']] Ubuntu 18.04 LTS Bionic Beaver<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2017/10/ubuntu-18-04-lts-called-bionic-beaver|title=Ubuntu 18.04 LTS is Called 'Bionic Beaver'|date=24 October 2017|website=''omgubuntu.co.uk''|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref> is a long term support version that was released on {{release date and age|2018|04|26}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2017/10/ubuntu-18-04-lts-release-schedule|title=Ubuntu 18.04 LTS Release Schedule - OMG! Ubuntu!|date=29 October 2017|website=''omgubuntu.co.uk''|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="1804rel">{{cite web|url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/BionicBeaver/ReleaseSchedule|title=BionicBeaver/ReleaseSchedule - Ubuntu Wiki|website=wiki.ubuntu.com|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref> and Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS was released three months later {{release date and age|2018|07|26}} <ref>http://fridge.ubuntu.com/2018/07/26/ubuntu-18-04-1-lts-released/</ref>. Plans to include a new [[Theme (computing)|theme]] created by the Ubuntu community, were announced on 5 February 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/02/install-the-new-ubuntu-theme|title=How to Try the New Ubuntu Theme|date=5 February 2018|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=14 March 2018}}</ref> However, as the development of the theme was unfinished and buggy as of 13 March 2018, Ubuntu 18.04 LTS did not include a new theme, and instead retained the Ambiance theme from 2010 as its default theme.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/03/ubuntu-18-04-lts-no-new-gtk-theme|title=Dang it! Ubuntu 18.04 Won't Include a New GTK Theme After All - OMG! Ubuntu!|date=13 March 2018|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=14 March 2018}}</ref> Still, the new theme will become available as a [[Snappy (package manager)|Snap package]].
Ubuntu 18.04 LTS introduced new features such as colour emoji,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2017/11/ubuntu-finally-long-last-time-support-color-emoji|title=Ubuntu 18.04 Will Support Color Emoji - OMG! Ubuntu!|date=8 November 2017|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=15 March 2018}}</ref> a new [[To do|To-Do]] app preinstalled in the default installation,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/01/ubuntu-18-04-new-app-to-do|title=Ubuntu 18.04 Adds a To-Do App to Default Install - OMG! Ubuntu!|date=27 January 2018|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=15 March 2018}}</ref> and added the option of a "Minimal Install" to the Ubuntu 18.04 LTS installer, which only installs a web browser and system tools.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/02/ubuntu-18-04-minimal-install-option|title=Ubuntu adds 'Minimal Install' option to installer - OMG! Ubuntu!|date=14 February 2018|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=15 March 2018}}</ref> Ubuntu 18.04 LTS's default [[display server]] was returned to [[X Window System|Xorg]] for more stability and reliability, however, [[Wayland (display server protocol)|Wayland]] is still included as part of the default install.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/01/xorg-will-default-display-server-ubuntu-18-04-lts|title=Ubuntu Drops Wayland, Switches back to Xorg - OMG! Ubuntu!|date=25 January 2018|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=15 March 2018}}</ref>
This release employed Linux kernel version 4.15, which incorporated a CPU controller for the [[cgroups|cgroup]] v2 interface, [[Zen_(microarchitecture)#Enhanced_security_and_virtualization_support|AMD secure memory encryption]] support and improved [[Serial ATA|SATA]] Link Power Management.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wiki.ubuntu.com/BionicBeaver/ReleaseNotes|title=BionicBeaver/ReleaseNotes - Ubuntu Wiki|website=wiki.ubuntu.com|accessdate=27 April 2018}}</ref>
In reviewing Ubuntu 18.04 LTS, Michael Larabel of [[Phoronix]] wrote, "Ubuntu 18.04 is mostly an incremental upgrade over Ubuntu 17.10 with updated packages, the switch back to X.Org session by default rather than Wayland, continued presence of Snaps, and a variety of minor user-interface updates. It's really not a big deal going from 17.10 to 18.04 besides the LTS extended support nature, but it is quite a change if upgrading from Ubuntu 16.04 LTS. For that upgrade you now have the [[GNU Compiler Collection|GCC]] 7 compiler, Unity 7 to [[GNOME Shell]] by default, and a wealth of other package updates."<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=news_item&px=Ubuntu-18.04-Download|title = Ubuntu 18.04 LTS "Bionic Beaver" Official Images Now Available|access-date = 27 April 2018|last = Larabel|first = Michael|work = [[Phoronix]]|date = 26 April 2018}}</ref>
In reviewing the Ubuntu 18.04 LTS server version, Michael Larabel of Phoronix, indicated that the newly developed text-based installer is an improvement over previous installers.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=news_item&px=Ubuntu-18.04-Server-Installer|title = The New Ubuntu 18.04 Server Installer Is Working Out Nicely|access-date = 27 April 2018|last = Larabel|first = Michael|work = [[Phoronix]]|date = 27 April 2018}}</ref>
On 15 November 2018, Mark Shuttleworth announced that Ubuntu 18.04 LTS would be supported for ten years, until April 2028.<ref name="Kerner"/>
===Ubuntu 18.10 (Cosmic Cuttlefish)=== [[File:Ubuntu 18.10.png|thumb|Ubuntu 18.10 ''Cosmic Cuttlefish'']]
On 8 May 2018, Mark Shuttleworth announced that the codename of Ubuntu 18.10, which was released on 18 October 2018,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/06/ubuntu-18-10-release-date-features|title=Ubuntu 18.10: Everything You Need to Know|date=2 June 2018|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=22 August 2018}}</ref> would be ''Cosmic Cuttlefish''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/1521 |title=Cue the Cosmic Cuttlefish |author=Mark Shuttleworth}}</ref>
The Ubuntu 18.10 installation includes a new theme, named ''Yaru''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/07/yaru-ubuntu-theme|title=The Ubuntu 'Communitheme' Has a New Name - OMG! Ubuntu!|date=24 July 2018|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=22 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/08/ubuntu-18-10-daily-builds-ship-with-new-default-theme|title=Ubuntu 18.10 Daily Builds Ship with New Default Theme - OMG! Ubuntu!|date=20 August 2018|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=22 August 2018}}</ref> and the new icon theme, ''Suru''.
Installation speeds are faster due to a [[lossless compression]] algorithm known as [[Zstandard]]. Startup speeds of pre-installed [[Snappy (package manager)|Snap applications]] were also improved.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/09/ubuntu-18-10-beta-download-out|title=Ubuntu 18.10 Beta is Now Available to Download - OMG! Ubuntu!|date=28 September 2018|work=OMG! Ubuntu!|access-date=2 October 2018}}</ref>
In a review of 18.10 Joey Sneddon of ''OMG Ubuntu'' wrote, "Ubuntu 18.10 'Cosmic Cuttlefish' is a modest update compared to 18.04. The vast majority of notable improvements are tucked away out of sight, 'under the hood' ... Upstream GNOME Shell developers spent the past six months trying to lower GNOME Shell's memory usage and improve the overall performance of the shell, its animations, display manager, and parts of the GNOME extension framework (specifically Gjs), as we touched on in our recap of the new features in GNOME 3.30. Invisible and abstract though these changes are, they're appreciable. So much so that, if I had to describe this release in just one word it'd be 'peppy'. That's testament to the power of collaboration; with upstream devs and Canonical's engineering team working together."<ref>{{cite web|url =https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/10/ubuntu-18-10-released-review |title = Ubuntu 18.10 released, but is it worth downloading?|access-date = 19 October 2018|last =Sneddon |first =Joey |work =OMG Ubuntu |date = 19 October 2018}}</ref>
Michael Larabel of [[Phoronix]] wrote, "Overall, Ubuntu 18.10 "Cosmic Cuttlefish" is quite a modest six-month upgrade for being the first past the Ubuntu 18.04 cycle. Exciting me the most, of course, is simply the package upgrades with riding Linux 4.18 + Mesa 18.2 for a much better Linux gaming experience and having moved on now to GCC8 ... What didn't get achieved for the Ubuntu 18.10 cycle is the long-awaited data viewer to the Ubuntu software/hardware survey introduced in 18.04 LTS... As of writing there's still no public means of being able to view the statistics on these opt-in Ubuntu survey installations. Additionally, the plans for better Android phone integration with the Ubuntu 18.10 desktop by means of bundling GS Connect also didn't happen as planned for the Ubuntu 18.10 cycle."<ref>{{cite web|url =https://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=news_item&px=Ubuntu-18.10-Releasing-Todayiew |title = Ubuntu 18.10 Set For Release Today With Some Nice Improvements|access-date = 5 November 2018 |last =Larabel |first =Micheal |work =[[Phoronix]] |date = 18 October 2018}}</ref>
===Ubuntu 19.04 (Disco Dingo)=== Ubuntu 19.04, codenamed ''Disco Dingo'', is a future release which is scheduled for 18 April 2019.<ref name="DiscoRel">{{cite web|url =https://wiki.ubuntu.com/DiscoDingo/ReleaseSchedule |title = Disco Dingo Release Schedule|access-date = 4 November 2018|author= [[Canonical Ltd]]|work = ubuntu.com|date = 30 October 2018|year= }}</ref>

==Version timeline== {{Timeline Ubuntu Linux}}
==Version end of life== After each version of Ubuntu has reached its [[End-of-life (product)|end-of-life]] time, its [[Software repository|repositories]] are removed from the main Ubuntu servers and consequently the mirrors.<ref>{{cite mailing list |url=https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/ubuntu-mirrors-announce/2007-May/000010.html |title=Old packages from unsupported Ubuntu releases will be removed from archive.ubuntu.com |last=Moffitt |first=Nick |mailinglist=ubuntu-mirrors-announce |date=31 May 2007 |accessdate=1 December 2008}}</ref> Older versions of Ubuntu repositories and releases can be found on the old Ubuntu releases website.<ref name="oldrepos">{{cite web |url=http://releases.ubuntu.com/ |title=Ubuntu Releases |publisher=Ubuntu |accessdate=11 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://old-releases.ubuntu.com/releases/ |title=Old Ubuntu Releases |publisher=Old-releases.ubuntu.com |accessdate=17 July 2013}}</ref>
